title: DeepMind Researcher Starts Robotics Company Backed by Nvidia and Recent Israeli Tech Developments
summary:
- Infinite Uptime raised $35 million in Series C funding to expand in the U.S. and improve factory maintenance solutions.
- The startup's solutions saved 74,274 hours of downtime and improved various operational metrics.
- Tray.ai acquired Israeli AI startup Vanti in a multi-million dollar deal to enhance its platform.
- Vanti specializes in AI for optimizing manufacturing processes and has raised $22 million since its founding.
- Israel is recognized as a "startup nation" with significant investment in its tech sector.
- Pete Florence, a senior researcher at DeepMind, has left Google to establish a robotics startup named [Generalist AI](https://generalistai.com/).
- The startup has received backing from Nvidia, as announced during a panel at the GTC conference.
- Florence aims to develop general-purpose robots, stating a desire to reduce the marginal cost of physical labor to zero.
- Other DeepMind alumni have similarly founded companies in robotics and AI.

sources.title: Infinite Uptime bags $35M to help factories optimize equipment usage
US tech firm Tray.ai acquires Israeli AI startup in multi-million deal
Israel’s top-funded tech companies in the last decade
A key DeepMind robotics researcher left Google and Nvidia has already backed his stealth startup

title: Bluesky CEO's T-shirt Sales Surpass Custom Domains Revenue
summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber wore a T-shirt with *Mundus sine Caesaribus* at SXSW, mocking Mark Zuckerberg.
- The T-shirt sold out in about 30 minutes after a surge of interest on Bluesky.
- Graber's shirt is a retort to Zuckerberg's *Aut Zuck aut nihil*, emphasizing decentralization.
- Bluesky earned more money from T-shirt sales in one day than in two years from custom domain sales.
- T-shirts sold for $40, quickly leading to a restock of orders.
- Custom domain sales remained low due to minimal promotion and lack of app integration.

sources.title: Bluesky quickly sold out of the T-shirt its CEO wore to troll Mark Zuckerberg
Bluesky made more money selling t-shirts mocking Zuckerberg than custom domains

title: Analogue’s Pocket Dock now works with all of Nintendo’s retro wireless controllers
summary:
- Analogue released a firmware update (PocketOS v2.5) for the Pocket handheld, fixing bugs and adding wireless controller support.
- The update improves compatibility for NES and Sega Genesis controllers, previously unsupported without a dongle.
- Pocket supports retro game cartridges from older handhelds like Game Boy and Sega Game Gear, with FPGA architecture allowing usage of gamepads for specific ROMs.
- Analogue also announced a delay for its 4K Nintendo 64 console, expected to ship by July 2025.

sources.title: Analogue’s Pocket Dock now works with all of Nintendo’s retro wireless controllers

title: DOGE Faces Legal Challenges Amid Major Overhaul in Government Tech
summary:
- A federal judge ruled Elon Musk's DOGE leadership likely violates the U.S. Constitution’s appointments clause.
- The lawsuit from USAID workers claims Musk, as a special advisor, exerts authority of a properly appointed officer.
- The ruling mandates restoration of certain USAID operations, restricting further changes by Musk's DOGE.
- Technology Transformation Services (TTS) under DOGE is experiencing major staff reductions and focus adjustments.
- TTS director Thomas Shedd has called for staff to achieve 'wins' amidst plans to cut staff by at least half.

sources.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE leadership likely violates constitution’s appointments clause, judge says
DOGE is demanding ‘wins’ from this elite government tech group—while promising major layoffs

title: Telegram founder Pavel Durov says app now has 1B users, calls WhatsApp a ‘cheap, watered down imitation’
summary:
- Telegram founder Pavel Durov announced the app has surpassed 1 billion active users, up from 950 million last year.
- Last year, Telegram registered $547 million in profits and became profitable in December 2024.
- Durov criticized WhatsApp, labeling it as a cheap imitation of Telegram, and highlighted Telegram’s independence and growth despite competition.
- Outside of China, WhatsApp leads in chat platforms with over 2 billion monthly active users.
- Both platforms compete to attract businesses and creators with features like business accounts and channels.
- Telegram appeals to crypto enthusiasts by integrating the TON blockchain and enabling decentralized apps for various functionalities.

sources.title: Telegram founder Pavel Durov says app now has 1B users, calls WhatsApp a ‘cheap, watered down imitation’

title: xAI launches an API for generating images
summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, has launched an image generation API called "grok-2-image-1212."
- The model can generate up to 10 images per request, limited to 5 requests per second, at $0.07 per image.
- xAI’s pricing is comparable to partners and competitors, with Black Forest Labs charging around $0.05 per image and Ideogram $0.08.
- The API currently does not allow adjustments to image quality, size, or style, and prompts are subject to revision by a "chat model."
- xAI is reportedly seeking a $10 billion funding round, aiming for a valuation of $75 billion and is expanding its data center in Memphis.

sources.title: xAI launches an API for generating images

title: Judge Orders Citibank to Release Nonprofit Funds, Rejects EPA's Arguments
summary:
- A federal judge ruled the EPA acted arbitrarily when terminating contracts with three nonprofits, issuing a temporary restraining order.
- The order requires the EPA and Citibank to restore access to frozen accounts linked to the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund.
- The judge found the EPA's claims of waste and fraud were vague and lacked specific evidence, noting the nonprofits faced imminent harm without fund access.
- Plaintiffs have committed substantial funds to renewable projects, now jeopardized by the account freezes.
- The ruling indicates strong likelihood of success in the nonprofits' case against the EPA's actions.
- The nonprofits had significant financial commitments, including Climate United's $392 million and Power Forward's $539 million, which were impacted by the funding freeze.
- The EPA provided vague reasons for contract terminations and failed to follow necessary procedures prior to account freezes.

sources.title: EPA was ‘arbitrary and capricious’ when it froze nonprofits’ Citibank accounts, judge finds
Judge orders Citibank to release nonprofit funds, rejects EPA’s arguments

title: Elon Musk’s X reportedly bounces back to $44B valuation
summary:
- The value of Elon Musk’s platform X has soared back to the $44bn he purchased it for.
- Investors valued it at $44bn in a secondary deal, a significant increase from a $10bn valuation by Fidelity in September.
- X is attempting to raise $2bn in new equity as it faces over $1bn in junior debt.
- Musk has faced declining revenue since acquiring the platform but reported adjusted profits of $1.2bn last year.
- The valuation rebound is attributed to a secondary deal that will help set a price for the primary funding round.
- X's valuation has reportedly bounced back to **$44 billion** according to the **Financial Times**.
- Elon Musk purchased the platform (formerly Twitter) for $44 billion in 2022.
- A separate **Bloomberg** report indicates that X raised close to **$1 billion** in funding, valuing the company at around **$32 billion**.
- Musk himself participated in the equity raise.
- X's valuation dropped as low as **$10 billion** last September according to **Fidelity Investments**.
- Despite a revenue decline since Musk's takeover, X reported **$1.2 billion** in adjusted earnings for 2024.

sources.title: Value of Elon Musk’s X ‘rebounds to $44bn purchase price’
Elon Musk’s X reportedly bounces back to $44B valuation

title: Former Game Informer staff tease a possible revival
summary:
- GameStop shut down Game Informer last year, leading to layoffs of all staff.
- A cryptic social media post suggests a possible return of the magazine with a teaser for March 25th.
- Former staff members are involved in the hints, raising hopes that the magazine will return with its original team.

sources.title: Former Game Informer staff tease a possible revival

title: Ribbit Capital Raises $500M Fund Amid Growing Fintech Investments
summary:
- 61 US startups became unicorns in 2024, with xAI valued at $24 billion.
- Global fintech investment reached $25.9 billion in Q4 2024, a rise from Q3.
- Wipro Limited announced a $200 million investment in AI and cybersecurity startups.
- Thailand's fintech struggles due to major banks controlling 82% of loans.
- Bessemer Venture Partners launched a $350 million fund for early-stage Indian startups.
- Ex-Indian fintech unicorn executives launched an asset management venture with innovative strategies.
- Ribbit Capital is raising $500 million for its new fund, Ribbit Capital Y, after raising $800 million in 2023 for Ribbit Capital X.
- Ribbit has invested in major fintech firms like Nubank and Robinhood, as well as crypto companies.

title: Nissan Tests Driverless Vehicles as GM, Gatik, and Torc Collaborate with Nvidia
summary:
- Nissan's driverless vehicles equipped with 14 cameras, 9 radars, and 6 LiDar sensors are being tested in Yokohama.
- Plans to deploy 20 vehicles in the area by 2029 or 2030 aim for Level Four automation.
- Japan faces competition in autonomous driving from China and the U.S., alongside addressing public safety concerns.
- Nvidia enhances self-driving technology at its GTC conference, expanding partnerships with GM, Gatik, and Torc.
- Gatik uses Nvidia’s Drive AGX for AI-powered autonomous trucks, while Torc targets a commercial launch in 2027.

sources.title: Nissan is testing driverless vehicles in city streets
GM, Gatik, Torc team up with Nvidia to accelerate self-driving

title: Plex Pass Price Increase and New Remote Playback Requirements
summary:
- Plex announces price increase for Plex Pass effective April 29.
- Monthly subscription rises from $4.99 to $6.99; yearly from $39.99 to $69.99; lifetime from $119.99 to $249.99.
- Remote streaming will now require a Plex Pass, with a new $1.99 Remote Watch Pass as an alternative.
- Local streaming from mobile app to be free without Plex Pass.
- New policies introduced regarding Plex activity; personal media data will not be shared or sold.
- Price hike attributed to rising operational costs and plans for new features like Common Sense Media integration.

sources.title: Streamer Plex raises subscription price for the first time in a decade
Plex Pass is going up in price — and now you'll need it for remote playback

title: Streaming Services Continue to Raise Prices: The Latest Updates
summary:
- Streaming services have been constantly increasing subscription prices, including Netflix, Disney Plus, Hulu, and others.
- Budget pressures arise from lost cable subscribers and increasing content costs in a competitive market.
- Providers increasingly restrict password sharing and eliminate lower-cost tiers, forcing viewers into pricier plans.
- Tracking current price changes across various platforms, with price hikes for services such as Plex, Amazon Music, and Fubo.
- Netflix's prices have dramatically increased, raising its standard plan to $17.99, reflecting a pattern of escalating costs in streaming.

sources.title: Streaming Services Continue to Raise Prices: The Latest Updates

title: Google Faces EU Antitrust Charges for Search and Play Store Practices
summary:
- Google is accused of violating EU antitrust laws by favoring its own services over competitors in search results.
- The European Commission's preliminary ruling mentions Alphabet's breach of the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by restricting app developers on the Play Store.
- Google faces potential fines of up to $35 billion if found guilty of DMA violations.
- Changes in Google Search could result in higher ticket prices for consumers and traffic declines for some businesses.
- The EU's investigation into Google Search started on March 25, 2024, following previous fines in 2017.
- Alphabet was designated as a 'gatekeeper' under the DMA in September 2023.
- The compliance deadline for the DMA is set for March 6, 2024.
- Violations of the DMA could lead to fines of up to 10% of Google's global annual turnover.
- Google claims compliance changes may harm consumers and hinder innovation, potentially leading to safety risks.

sources.title: Google Search charged with breaking EU antitrust rules
Google search, Play Store falling foul of Digital Markets Act rules, says EU

title: All the news about Netflix’s gaming efforts
summary: - Netflix continues to explore gaming, with announcements about new content and titles. - Upcoming March 18 release of Kid Cosmo, a puzzle game launching alongside The Electric State movie. - Netflix's co-CEO Greg Peters mentioned plans for cloud gaming and co-op games, likening it to family board game nights. - The company plans to cut down on its interactive titles, keeping only a few existing options. - Recently, notable games like Unleashed based on Squid Game were released, while other popular games continue gaining traction in their lineup.

sources.title: All the news about Netflix’s gaming efforts

title: Analytics company Dataminr secures $85M to fund growth
summary:
- Dataminr raised $85 million in convertible financing and credit, aimed at accelerating growth.
- The company previously raised $475 million in 2021 at a $4.1 billion valuation but faced layoffs of 20% of staff in November 2023.
- The new funding focuses on expanding operations in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia, as well as developing new AI-driven products.
- CEO Ted Bailey highlighted that this round doesn't set a valuation and was led by NightDragon and HSBC.
- Dataminr provides tools for real-time event monitoring and serves over 800 clients, including the U.S. Department of Defense.
- The company faced controversy over its surveillance practices but claims to continuously improve its technology.

sources.title: Analytics company Dataminr secures $85M to fund growth

title: Tera AI comes out of stealth with $7.8M to provide visual navigation for robots
summary:
- Tera AI raises $7.8 million in seed funding to develop zero-shot navigation for robots.
- The company aims to provide affordable, software-based visual navigation that is hardware agnostic.
- CEO Tony Zhang believes this technology can enable robots to operate in various environments without expensive sensors.

sources.title: Tera AI comes out of stealth with $7.8M to provide visual navigation for robots

title: Singapore explores AI-driven defense autonomy with Anduril
summary:
- Singapore's Defence Science and Technology Agency (DSTA) partners with Anduril Industries and the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) to enhance mission autonomy.
- The collaboration will utilize Anduril's Lattice for Mission Autonomy software to develop autonomous behaviors for improved decision-making in the field.
- Simulation demonstrations are planned for testing these behaviors over the next year.
- This partnership represents Anduril's first international collaboration for its mission autonomy platform.

sources.title: Singapore explores AI-driven defense autonomy with Anduril

title: Mistral AI partners with Singapore’s Defense Ministry
summary:
- Singapore’s Ministry of Defence collaborates with Mistral AI to enhance decision-making in the Armed Forces.
- Focus on developing generative AI models, including a tailored mixture-of-experts model.
- The partnership aims to improve information retrieval and AI-driven decision support systems in secure environments.

sources.title: Mistral AI partners with Singapore’s Defense Ministry

title: Researchers say they’ve discovered a new method of ‘scaling up’ AI, but there’s reason to be skeptical
summary:
- Researchers explore a new AI scaling law called 'inference-time search' that may improve model performance.
- Inference-time search generates multiple answers in parallel and chooses the best one, claiming to enhance Google's Gemini 1.5 Pro model's performance.
- Experts are skeptical about the method's practicality, stating it may not be effective for general language interactions where clear evaluation isn't possible.

sources.title: Researchers say they’ve discovered a new method of ‘scaling up’ AI, but there’s reason to be skeptical

title: EU sends Apple first DMA interoperability instructions for apps and connected devices
summary:
- The EU has sent Apple preliminary instructions to comply with interoperability provisions in the Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- Apple must enable access to nine iOS connectivity features for third-party devices, improving compatibility.
- Apple argues the DMA's regulations could threaten user privacy and restrict innovation, calling them anti-competitive.

sources.title: EU sends Apple first DMA interoperability instructions for apps and connected devices

title: Google delays Pixel 9A release due to component quality issue
summary:
- Google’s Pixel 9A release has been delayed to April for quality checks.
- Pre-orders are not yet available, which is unusual for Google.
- A component quality issue affecting a small number of devices is under investigation.
- Review units have not been distributed yet.
- This delay follows previous issues with the Pixel 4A related to battery overheating and a warranty extension for display defects on the Pixel 8.
- The Pixel 9A is expected to have a 5,100mAh battery, the largest in Google’s phone lineup.

sources.title: Google delays Pixel 9A release due to component quality issue

title: Families of Tesla Crash Victims Urge Oversight on Autopilot Investigations
summary:
- Families of Tesla crash victims are urging the US Department of Transportation to maintain a reporting rule for crashes involving autonomous vehicles.
- They express concerns about Elon Musk's influence potentially weakening oversight of Tesla's technologies.
- The letter to Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy cites fears that the Biden-era rule may be discarded, benefiting Tesla's reporting advantages.
- Since the rule's implementation, Tesla has reported over 1,800 crashes, accounting for most fatal crashes reported to NHTSA.
- The families highlight the importance of continued oversight to ensure safety for drivers using Tesla's Autopilot and Full Self-Driving features.

sources.title: Families of Tesla Crash Victims Urge Oversight on Autopilot Investigations

title: US teachers’ union says hackers stole sensitive personal data on over 500,000 members
summary:
- The Pennsylvania State Education Association (PSEA) reported a data breach affecting over 517,000 members' sensitive personal information.
- The breach, confirmed in a filing with Maine’s attorney general, occurred during a cyberattack in July 2024.
- Stolen data includes government IDs, Social Security numbers, passport numbers, medical information, and financial details like card numbers and PINs.
- PSEA indicated some data elements were not acquired for every individual and took steps to ensure data was deleted post-breach, hinting at a ransomware or data extortion attack.
- There is no guarantee that paying the ransom ensures the deletion of the stolen data, as seen in previous ransomware incidents.

sources.title: US teachers’ union says hackers stole sensitive personal data on over 500,000 members

title: Hugging Face’s new iOS app taps AI to describe what you’re looking at
summary:
- Hugging Face launched an iOS app called [HuggingSnap](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/huggingsnap/id6742157364) that uses offline AI to describe camera views in real-time.
- The app employs Hugging Face’s in-house vision model, smolvlm2, to identify objects and explain scenes without sending data to the cloud.
- It requires iOS 18 or later and also works with macOS devices and Apple Vision Pro for broader compatibility.

sources.title: Hugging Face’s new iOS app taps AI to describe what you’re looking at

title: Microsoft Fixes Copilot Uninstall Bug for Windows 11 Devices
summary:
- Microsoft has resolved an issue that caused Copilot to be unintentionally uninstalled from some Windows 11 devices.
- Affected devices are being restored to their original state following the fix.
- The issue was noted in a March 11 update and users were advised to reinstall Copilot manually from the Microsoft Store while a permanent fix was in progress.
- Copilot was recently launched as a native Windows app with enhanced features, including a new UI and a voice chat shortcut.

sources.title: Microsoft Fixes Copilot Uninstall Bug for Windows 11 Devices

title: ‘The Last of Us’ to stream in American Sign Language on Max
summary:
- Max announced the HBO series "The Last of Us" will stream in American Sign Language (ASL).
- This is the first time HBO’s content is available in ASL, enhancing accessibility for deaf and hard-of-hearing viewers.
- Season 2 premieres on April 13, 2025, and the first season will be available in ASL starting March 31, 2025.
- ASL versions will feature performances by ‘Coda’ actor Daniel Durant and ASL performer Leila Hanaumi.
- Other titles available in ASL on Max include "Barbie," "Beetlejuice," and "Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire."

sources.title: ‘The Last of Us’ to stream in American Sign Language on Max

title: Nvidia cuts RTX 50-series prices across Europe
summary:
- Nvidia has cut prices on RTX 50-series GPUs across Europe by nearly 5% due to a stronger Euro.
- The RTX 5090 price dropped from €2,329 to €2,229, the RTX 5080 from €1,169 to €1,119, and the RTX 5070 from €649 to €619.
- The RTX 5070 Ti's price remains unchanged at €879 as it was not released as a Founders Edition.
- In the UK, the RTX 5090 is now priced at £1,889 down from £1,939.
- Despite price reductions, stock availability remains low for RTX 50-series cards across Europe.

sources.title: Nvidia cuts RTX 50-series prices across Europe

title: What does OpenAI really want from Trump?
summary:
- OpenAI submitted a policy proposal to the White House's AI Action Plan, highlighting concerns over AI regulation.
- The proposal seeks to preempt state laws like California’s SB 1047, which would impose strict liability and protection measures for AI development.
- There are currently 893 AI-related bills being considered across 48 states in 2025, reflecting a surge in legislative activity on AI.
- OpenAI and the tech industry argue that a fragmented regulatory landscape would create chaos, calling for federal preemption without providing a clear national framework.
- The focus on countering China is a recurring theme in OpenAI's proposal, emphasizing national security and economic competitiveness.

sources.title: What does OpenAI really want from Trump?

title: Boston Dynamics Atlas Robot Evolution and Nvidia's Open Foundation Model Announcement
summary:
- Nvidia announced Isaac GR00T N1, an open-source model for humanoid robots.
- CEO Jensen Huang declared, "The age of generalist robotics is here."
- The framework emphasizes human-robot companionship rather than tool functionality.
- Demonstrations featured NEO Gamma robot using the GR00T N1 model.
- Early adopters include Boston Dynamics and Agility Robotics.
- GR00T N1 has a dual-system architecture: quick reflex actions and planning.
- Developers can customize the model using training data from human tasks.
- The model translates visual input into motor actions with a Diffusion Transformer at 120 Hz.
- It shows a 30% improvement in manipulation tasks.
- Demonstrated cross-embodiment capabilities with LeRobot SO100 robot arm.
- The initiative includes over 300,000 open-sourced simulated trajectories.
- Boston Dynamics showcases the evolution of their Atlas robot over the years.
- The latest version is all-electric and capable of advanced machine learning tasks.
- Atlas demonstrated improved agility and flexibility, proving it can perform sorting tasks in a simulated environment.
- The robot now boasts enhanced sensors for better manipulation of objects.
- Boston Dynamics revealed the new Atlas as part of their commitment to create robots that can handle complex tasks without human intervention.
- Video footage displays Atlas performing various tasks, highlighting its unique capabilities and potential applications in real-world scenarios.
- The company hinted at future developments and the ongoing importance of robotics in industries such as construction and manufacturing.

sources.title: Nvidia says ‘the age of generalist robotics is here’
Nvidia unveils ‘first open foundation model for humanoid robots’
Boston Dynamics Atlas robot: a full history

title: Threat posed by new VMware hyperjacking vulnerabilities is hard to overstate
summary:
- Three critical vulnerabilities in VMware's virtual-machine products can allow hackers extensive access to sensitive environments.
- Known as hyperjacking or hypervisor attacks, these vulnerabilities let attackers break out of isolated VM environments and access multiple customers’ VMs.
- Security researcher Kevin Beaumont warns that escaping to the hypervisor enables access to all systems, disrupting boundaries that isolate customers.
- VMware has indicated that these vulnerabilities are actively being exploited and affect all supported and unsupported versions of its ESXi, Workstation, Fusion, Cloud Foundation, and Telco Cloud Platform.

sources.title: Threat posed by new VMware hyperjacking vulnerabilities is hard to overstate

title: Go Module Mirror served backdoor to devs for 3+ years
summary:
- A backdoored package was served via the Go Module Mirror by Google for over three years.
- The malicious version was named boltdb-go/bolt, targeting users of the legitimate boltdb/bolt module.
- The issue arose from typosquatting, where users could inadvertently download the backdoored package due to minor name variations.
- Researchers petitioned for its removal after spotting the malicious code, which was cached despite a revert to the legitimate version on GitHub.

sources.title: Go Module Mirror served backdoor to devs for 3+ years

title: The AI leaders bringing the AGI debate down to Earth
summary:
- Dario Amodei, CEO of Anthropic, predicts powerful AI could arrive by 2026, claiming it might surpass Nobel Prize winners in intelligence.
- Thomas Wolf, Hugging Face co-founder, questions the feasibility of AGI from current AI models; believes significant breakthroughs require novel questions.
- Demis Hassabis of Google DeepMind suggests AGI may be a decade away, highlighting current AI limitations.
- Kenneth Stanley from Lila Sciences emphasizes the need for creativity in AI development, arguing that current models lack originality and subjective problem-solving capabilities.
- AI leaders advocating for a rigorous evaluation of AGI prospects aim to advance the conversation about achieving genuine artificial general intelligence.

sources.title: The AI leaders bringing the AGI debate down to Earth

title: Hunted Labs lands $3M to find suspicious open source contributors
summary:
- Former NSA deputy director George Barnes makes his first investment as a venture capitalist with a $3M seed deal for Hunted Labs.
- Hunted Labs aims to assess the trustworthiness of open source software contributors, addressing security issues highlighted by a 2024 backdoor discovery.
- The startup secured a $1.79M contract with the Space Development Agency and is part of Red Cell's incubator for support and mentorship.

sources.title: Hunted Labs lands $3M to find suspicious open source contributors

title: TSMC’s Massive Arizona Chips Project Praised by Taiwan’s President
summary:
- Taiwan’s President William Lai praised TSMC’s $100 billion investment in Arizona as a model for building non-Chinese chip supply chains.
- TSMC plans to build three chip foundries, an R&D center, and two packaging facilities, adding to a previous $65 billion commitment.
- The investment is driven by customer demand, not U.S. administration pressure; TSMC assures that U.S. plans won’t affect production in Taiwan.
- The project is set to create 40,000 construction jobs and additional tech and manufacturing jobs over four years.
- Arizona's Governor Katie Hobbs highlighted the benefits for advanced manufacturing and global technology advancements.

sources.title: TSMC’s Massive Arizona Chips Project Praised by Taiwan’s President

title: Razer launches new Wyvrn game dev platform with automated AI bug tester
summary:
- Razer introduces the Wyvrn developer platform featuring tools like AI QA Copilot for game testing and AI Gamer Copilot for real-time in-game tips.
- AI QA Copilot is a cloud-based plug-in designed to enhance quality assurance by automatically identifying bugs and optimizing testing time and costs.
- The platform also integrates Razer's Chroma RGB, THX Spatial Audio Plus, and Sensa HD Haptics software, with a partnership planned with Side for QA integration.

sources.title: Razer launches new Wyvrn game dev platform with automated AI bug tester

title: Google unveils redesigned $499 Pixel 9a
summary:
- Google announced the Pixel 9A, starting at $499.
- Features a 6.3-inch screen with 2,700 nits peak brightness.
- New Tensor G4 processor and better IP68 water resistance.
- Ditches the camera bump for a flush design, includes a 48MP main camera and 13MP ultrawide.
- Battery capacity increased to 5,100mAh with Qi wireless and 23W wired charging.
- Available with 8GB RAM and 128GB storage for $499; 256GB for $599.
- Seven years of OS upgrades and security support for longevity.
- The device comes in four colors: Peony, Iris, Porcelain, and Obsidian.
- AI-powered photography features include various editing tools and enhanced night modes.

sources.title: The Pixel 9A is a midrange phone that actually looks like a good deal
Google unveils redesigned $499 Pixel 9a

title: The weeklong TikTok fight over whether NYC influencers are ‘boring’
summary:
- A TikTok clip criticizing NYC influencers as 'boring' sparked widespread discourse.
- The clip was posted by user @martinifeeny and highlighted similarities among influencers' content and lifestyles.
- Responses included calls for more diverse influencer representation and reactions from the influencers themselves.
- The phenomenon reflects broader patterns in social media where homogeneity in content creation is common due to algorithmic pressures.
- The article argues that this trend is not an anomaly but a result of advertising incentives and technological constraints.

sources.title: The weeklong TikTok fight over whether NYC influencers are ‘boring’

title: Day One brings its digital journaling app to Windows
summary:
- Automattic-owned Day One launched a Windows version of its journaling app, available on the Microsoft Store.
- The app offers a distraction-free experience similar to other platforms, is free to use, and currently does not count against the one-device syncing limit.
- Features include unlimited text entries, multimedia integration, local storage with end-to-end encryption, and plans for future AI enhancements such as context-aware journaling prompts.

sources.title: Day One brings its digital journaling app to Windows

title: Cape opens $99/month beta of its privacy-first mobile plan, inks Proton deal, raises $30M
summary:
- Cape launches a privacy-focused mobile service at $99/month in open beta.
- Partnership established with Proton, offering additional privacy services.
- Raised $30 million in equity and debt funding to support growth.
- New mobile plan includes unlimited voice, texts, data, and encrypted voicemail without data tracking.
- Cape's founders include former Palantir national security head; targeting users seeking privacy control.
- Protection measures against SIM swapping and SS7 vulnerabilities included in the service.
- General availability of the service expected later in 2025.

sources.title: Cape opens $99/month beta of its privacy-first mobile plan, inks Proton deal, raises $30M

title: Zoox recalls software on 258 self-driving cars over unexpected braking
summary:
- Zoox issues a voluntary recall for 258 self-driving cars due to hard braking issues in its autonomous driving system.
- The recall follows a preliminary investigation by the NHTSA after reports of motorcyclist collisions with Zoox vehicles.
- Affected vehicles include those with software versions released before November 5, 2024; a software update was implemented by November 7, 2024.
- Recall includes purpose-built robotaxis, which are being tested in San Francisco and Las Vegas.
- The decision comes amid increased regulatory scrutiny following prior safety incidents in the autonomous vehicle industry.

sources.title: Zoox recalls software on 258 self-driving cars over unexpected braking

title: What happened to Netflix’s big bet on gaming?
summary:
- In 2021, Netflix's VP of game development, Mike Verdu, announced a major gaming initiative. 
- By the end of 2022, only about 1% of Netflix subscribers engaged with its games. 
- Netflix has since canceled several games and restructured its gaming departments, indicating a pivot in strategy following slow growth and stalled development.

sources.title: What happened to Netflix’s big bet on gaming?

title: Google Wallet Expands Access for Kids with Tap-to-Pay Feature
summary:
- Google Wallet will now let kids download the app for tap-to-pay in select countries with parental consent.
- The feature will be available in the US, UK, Australia, Spain, and Poland and allows kids to store event tickets, library cards, and gift cards.
- Parents control the payment card addition process through the Family Link app and get email notifications for each transaction.
- Online purchases are prohibited, and kids can only add payment cards with parental permission.
- The feature rollout begins in the coming weeks and requires parents to verify their identity in the app to add a card.
- This initiative resembles Apple's Apple Cash Family offerings.

sources.title: Google Wallet is adding tap-to-pay for kids
Google now lets kids use Google Wallet for in-store payments in select countries

title: Vote for Your Favorite Speaker at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
summary:

title: Amazon Faces AI Copyright Challenges and Changes to Echo Voice Recording Policies
summary:
- Amazon Echo users lose local processing of voice recordings, effective March 28.
- Users with the “Do Not Send Voice Recordings” setting have been notified of this change.
- The transition supports new generative AI features reliant on Amazon’s cloud.
- Amazon settled a $25 million FTC lawsuit in 2023 addressing children's privacy violations.
- Amazon's AI song generation platform, Suno, is under legal scrutiny for potential copyright infringement.
- Major music labels and the RIAA are suing Suno for using copyrighted materials without authorization.
- Suno contends its use fits under fair use despite possibly using copyrighted music for training.
- The integration of Suno with Alexa raises concerns about impacts on artists and original music.
- Legal issues regarding fair use in AI-generated content remain unresolved, highlighted by past Supreme Court rulings.
- Suno may face significant damages if found guilty of infringement, impacting the music industry.

sources.title: Amazon’s Echo will send all voice recordings to the cloud, starting March 28
Amazon is blundering into an AI copyright nightmare

title: Google Acquires Wiz for $33 Billion to Strengthen Cloud Security
summary:
- Google is acquiring cloud security startup Wiz for $33 billion, the largest acquisition in its history.
- The deal is pending regulatory approval and has not been officially confirmed by either company.
- Acquisition aims to strengthen Google's position in the enterprise cloud and security market, currently lagging behind AWS and Microsoft Azure.
- Wiz's projected annual recurring revenue (ARR) for this year is $1 billion, up from $500 million last year.
- If finalized, this acquisition will exceed Google's $12.5 billion purchase of Motorola Mobility in 2012.
- Wiz's products will remain available on competing platforms due to antitrust concerns.
- Google Cloud's market share is 12%, compared to AWS's 30% and Azure's 21%, hence a multicloud strategy is essential.
- SoftBank's investment in Wiz in August 2024 has resulted in tripling its initial investment value after the acquisition.
- Wiz, founded in 2020, services nearly 45% of Fortune 100 companies and raised $1 billion at a valuation exceeding $12 billion in May 2024.
- The company expects to achieve a $1 billion revenue rate by 2025.
- This acquisition is noted as the largest tech deal in Israel's history, reflecting a heightened interest in cybersecurity.
- Google’s growth in security services and the acquisition of Wiz may enhance its appeal to potential customers in the rapidly evolving AI and cloud landscape.

sources.title: Google is buying Wiz for $33B to beef up in cloud security, sources say

SoftBank scores big as Google buys Wiz for $32b

title: The future of search isn’t Google — and it’s $10 a month
summary:
- Kagi is a paid search engine that costs $10/month and offers an ad-free experience with better search results.
- The service was created in response to concerns over Google's ad-centric model and data tracking practices.
- Kagi provides features like image and video search, along with customization options and various 'Lenses' to tailor search results.
- Users have full control over their search experience, including the ability to block certain domains and prioritize others.
- Kagi's index emphasizes quality over quantity, reducing SEO clutter often found in Google search results.
- Privacy is a priority as Kagi does not store user search data, although some third-party integrations may collect data.
- A free trial allows users to test Kagi with up to 100 searches before committing to a subscription.

title: Academics Raise Concerns Over AI Startups and Peer Review Practices
summary:
- Japanese startup Sakana claimed its AI-generated paper is the first to pass peer review, but with caveats.
- Sakana used AI called The AI Scientist-v2 to generate and submit three papers to an ICLR workshop, with one accepted before withdrawal for transparency.
- Critics note the acceptance rate is higher for workshops; many believe AI isn't ready to independently contribute to science yet.
- Controversy surrounds AI-generated studies submitted to the ICLR conference, raising ethical questions about peer review.
- Three AI labs (Sakana, Intology, Autoscience) generated studies; Sakana informed ICLR, while Intology and Autoscience did not.
- Academics express concern over the misuse of peer review, arguing it undermines the volunteer efforts of human reviewers.

sources.title: Sakana claims its AI-generated paper passed peer review — but it’s a bit more nuanced than that
Academics accuse AI startups of co-opting peer review for publicity

title: US paid music subscribers cross 100 million mark for the first time

- Streaming revenue accounted for 84% of total music revenue in 2024, equating to $14.9 billion, with paid subscriptions generating $11.7 billion, a 5% increase from the previous year.
- Pricing increases from streaming services like Spotify, Apple Music, and YouTube may have contributed to the higher revenues.

title: SG Competition Watchdog Confirms No Grab-GoTo Merger Notice Received as GoTo Reports Strong Growth

title: Overview of Tech Layoffs in 2024 and 2025
summary:
- Over 150,000 job cuts in 2024 across 542 tech companies.
- Significant layoffs at [Tesla](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/15/tesla-layoffs-workers-sales-cybertruck-cuts/), [Amazon](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/amazon-prime-video-and-mgm-studios-laid-off-hundreds-of-employees/), [Google](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/google-cuts-hundreds-of-jobs-in-its-voice-assistance-hardware-teams-as-fitbit-founders-leave/), [TikTok](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/23/tiktok-lays-off-60-employees/), [Snap](https://techcrunch.com/2024/02/05/snapchats-parent-lays-off-10-of-workforce-in-order-to-reduce-hierarchy-says-company/), and [Microsoft](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/25/microsoft-lays-off-1900-employees-in-activision-blizzard-and-xbox-divisions/).
- Layoff trends expected to persist into 2025, as tracked by [Layoffs.fyi](https://layoffs.fyi/).
- A shift towards AI and automation is impacting large companies and startups alike.
- Monthly layoffs tracked from January 2024 to early 2025, with 6,003 jobs cut in January 2025 and 2,268 in December 2024.
- In 2025, over 22,000 tech workers laid off, including 16,084 in February alone.
- Significant layoffs also reported by NASA, Wayfair, and TikTok affecting hundreds of employees.
- Siemens to cut approximately 5,600 jobs globally, focused on automation and electric vehicles.
- HelloFresh plans to lay off 273 jobs in Texas as part of site consolidation.
- Additional notable layoffs include 340 at Wayfair and 2,500 at HPE due to financial adjustments.

- The iPhone 16 is the best choice for most users, offering a balance of features at a lower price.
- iPhone 16 Pro is recommended for photography enthusiasts with its advanced camera features.
- iPhone 16 Pro Max is ideal for those seeking the best screen and battery life.
- The cheapest new iPhone is the iPhone 16e, suitable for budget-conscious buyers.

title: LG Launches South Korea’s First Open-Source AI Model Exaone Deep; Grab CEO Highlights AI's Role in Business Growth
summary:
- Grab CEO Anthony Tan stressed the necessity of AI adoption at [Converge Live](https://www.techinasia.com/news/grab-ceo-warns-ai-crucial-for-growth-non-users-risk-lagging) in Singapore, warning non-users may lag behind.
- Grab's AI solutions include a 'driver co-pilot' for job optimization and reducing wait times, contributing to a 19% revenue increase to US$2.8 billion in 2024.
- Tan plans to expand AI use among Grab's 7,000 employees and personally uses AI for coding and productivity enhancements.
- [Roblox](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/17/roblox-releases-its-open-source-model-that-can-create-3d-objects-using-ai/) unveiled its open-source 3D model "Cube," leveraging generative AI for creating 3D objects, available for external developers.
- Cube allows users to generate objects like cars from simple text prompts and includes additional AI tools such as text generation and speech recognition.
- Future enhancements for Roblox aim to increase complexity in object generation and dynamic environmental changes.
- [LG](https://www.techinasia.com/news/lg-unveils-south-koreas-opensource-ai-model-exaone-deep) has introduced Exaone Deep, the first open-source AI model in South Korea.
- This model is designed to enhance AI development and research within the region.
- Exaone Deep aims to provide flexible and accessible AI tools for developers and researchers.

sources.title: Grab CEO warns AI crucial for growth, non-users risk lagging
Roblox releases its open-source model that can create 3D objects using AI
LG unveils South Korea’s first open-source AI model Exaone Deep

title: Kindle Colorsoft review: Amazon’s new e-reader gets colour screen upgrade
summary:
- The Kindle Colorsoft is Amazon's first e-reader with a colour screen, priced at £270.
- It offers improvements in contrast and speed over competitors like Boox and Kobo.
- Features a 7-inch colour e-paper display with 150ppi for colour and 300ppi for black & white.
- While black and white text appears a bit greyer, the functionality of the device remains solid.
- Enhanced visual organization with coloured book covers and in-text visuals, making it easier to browse.
- Supports highlighting passages in various colours, with a fast and responsive touchscreen interface.
- Battery life lasts approximately 32 hours when reading colour graphic novels.
- Weight is 219g, and dimensions are 127.6 x 176.7 x 7.8mm with IPX8 water resistance rating.
- Retains basic Kindle features with a smooth black plastic design and a single physical button.
- Although it enhances reading experiences, the small screen size makes it less ideal for full-size graphic novels.

sources.title: Kindle Colorsoft review: Amazon’s new e-reader gets colour screen upgrade

- The Presidential Working Group is tasked with advancing the initiative.
- The SEC has relaxed regulations, dropping investigations into some cryptocurrencies.
- Trump's strategy aims to reduce regulatory hurdles for cryptocurrencies, utilizing taxpayer money in the reserve.
- Tariffs on imports are negatively impacting both stock and cryptocurrency markets.

title: Assassin’s Creed: Shadows – a historic frolic through feudal Japan
summary:

- Features a richly detailed environment with authentic landscapes and historical settings, including Kyoto and Osaka.
- Offers dual protagonists: Fujibayashi Naoe, a stealthy female shinobi, and Yasuke, a powerful black samurai.
- Players navigate through missions that involve repetitive quest structures.
- Combat system praised for one-on-one engagements but criticized for chaotic group interactions.
- Game releases on March 20, priced at £59.99.

title: Apple loses appeal in Germany, faces stricter market rules

- Apple's request to involve the European Court of Justice was denied, reinforcing German regulations on tech giants.
- The ruling increases scrutiny of Apple's App Store due to concerns regarding user data collection.

title: Samsung Faces AI Chip Challenges Amid Innovation Surge in Computing Companies
summary:
- Companies supporting AI infrastructure see a surge in innovation and revenue.
- Notable mentions:
 - **IBM**: Expanded quantum computing ecosystem, debuted efficient quantum systems, and gained 600,000 registrations for quantum usage.
 - **Lambda Labs**: Launched 1-Click service for instant GPU clusters for AI training, used by major companies and raised $320 million in funding.
 - **TSMC**: Launched state-of-the-art 3 nm processing technology with improvements for AI chips, achieving record revenue in 2024.
 - **SambaNova Systems**: Introduced SambaNova Cloud, focused on AI inference, adding several high-profile clients.
 - **Aligned Data Centers**: Rolled out innovative cooling technology and has extensive data center development plans.
 - **SiMa.ai**: Developed multi-modal AI chips for edge applications, focusing on energy efficiency.
 - **Oxide Computer**: Started selling plug-and-play cloud computers for secure local data processing, with notable government clients.
 - **NextSilicon**: Launched Maverick-2 chip for high-performance computing, focusing on dynamic hardware reconfiguration based on needs.
- Samsung Electronics is facing concerns about its ability to capitalize on the AI boom ahead of its annual general meeting on Mar. 18, 2025.
- The company is experiencing a decline in its competitive edge, particularly in semiconductors, trailing behind SK Hynix in high bandwidth memory chips needed for AI graphics processing.
- Internal communications indicate a focus on maintaining the status quo rather than driving innovation, raising worries about corporate stagnation.
- Recent developments include increasing R&D spending to a record high of $61 billion in 2024, amid tough competition from TSMC exploring a partnership with Intel.
- Several recent articles detail significant changes and events concerning Samsung's operations, including wage increases and recruitment efforts across its subsidiaries.

sources.title: The 10 most innovative computing companies of 2025
Samsung faces AI chip challenges

title: Oracle explores plan to address TikTok US security concerns
summary:
- Oracle is proposing a plan to address national security concerns regarding TikTok's operations in the US.
- The proposal includes providing data security assurances and potentially acquiring a stake in a new American entity.
- TikTok's algorithm will remain under ByteDance's control, raising US compliance concerns despite easing Chinese approval.
- The plan requires approval from the Trump administration, ByteDance, and Chinese authorities.
- Oracle is currently working with TikTok on Project Texas to secure US user data and prevent Chinese government backdoor access.
- TikTok's US operations are valued at up to $50 billion, with notable bidders including Frank McCourt and Alexis Ohanian.
- Vice President JD Vance is leading efforts towards a potential agreement to balance national security and TikTok's US operations.

- Operated by MINDEF’s Digital and Intelligence Service, it will enable AI integration for military uses.
- DSTA chief Ng Chad-Son emphasizes the transformative role of cloud and AI technologies in operational efficiency.

title: Pine Labs and GCash Prepare for Upcoming IPOs
summary:
- GCash plans to reduce public float to 10%-15% for its IPO, below the 20% minimum in the Philippines.
- Approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission is required, with discussions ongoing.
- The IPO could raise between US$1 billion and US$1.5 billion, aiming for a potential listing by the end of 2025.
- GCash is valued at US$5 billion and has approximately 94 million users.
- The company is diversifying beyond payments into lending and investment services.
- Pine Labs plans to launch its IPO in the second half of 2025, confirmed by CEO Amrish Rau.
- The IPO size remains undisclosed but sources indicate a potential US$1 billion issue.
- The company is currently valued between US$6 billion and US$8 billion, up from US$5 billion in 2022.
- Pine Labs provides payment solutions to over 500,000 merchants across India, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia.
- The company is shifting its domicile from Singapore to India, approved by the National Company Law Tribunal in August 2024.
- For FY24, Pine Labs reported operating revenue of 1,317 crore rupees (US$152.06 million) but a net loss of 187 crore rupees (US$21.59 million).
- If successful, this IPO could become the largest for an Indian fintech since Paytm’s US$2.5 billion listing in 2021.

title: Feds charge director with $11 million fraud over his unfinished Netflix show
summary:
- Prosecutors charged director Carl Erik Rinsch with wire fraud and money laundering related to a Netflix series.
- Netflix paid $44 million for Rinsch's unfinished show originally titled *White Horse*, later renamed *Conquest*.
- Rinsch allegedly requested an additional $11 million, which he misappropriated for personal use after Netflix provided it in 2020.
- Prosecutors claim he lost over half of part of the funds in a brokerage account and spent $10 million on personal luxuries, including luxury cars and legal fees.
- The show remains incomplete, and Rinsch's erratic behavior led to Netflix terminating the development in 2021.

sources.title: Feds charge director with $11 million fraud over his unfinished Netflix show

title: Trump Fires Democratic FTC Commissioners, Claims of Illegal Dismissal Arise
summary:
- President Trump fired the two remaining Democratic commissioners at the FTC, leading to claims of illegal dismissal.
- Commissioner Alvaro Bedoya called the firing an act of corruption, while Rebecca Kelly Slaughter emphasized its violation of legal precedents.
- The firings are viewed as an attempt to minimize regulatory scrutiny over corporations by a Republican-majority FTC.
- Bedoya plans to testify before Colorado's Joint House and Senate Judiciary Committees and pursue legal action against his dismissal.
- This action challenges a 1935 Supreme Court precedent that protects FTC commissioners from being fired without "good cause."
- Slaughter described the firings as "illegal," claiming they violate statutory language and Court precedent.
- The FTC is responsible for enforcing consumer protection and antitrust laws, and typically has five members.

sources.title: Democratic FTC commissioners say they were just ‘illegally fired’ by President Trump
Trump Fires FTC Commissioners, Setting Up a Legal Battle

title: JD Vance claims freeing AI from regulation is good for American workers and tech innovators
summary:
• Vice President JD Vance emphasized AI and tech innovations benefiting both populists and tech investors at the Andreessen Horowitz American Dynamism Summit in Washington, D.C.
• Vance noted that fears of AI replacing jobs overlook that innovation often creates higher-paying jobs, citing the historical example of bank tellers displaced by ATMs.
• He criticized past government actions and proposed fewer regulations on AI to stimulate tech innovation while suggesting adjustments to trade and immigration policies to discourage offshoring.

sources.title: JD Vance claims freeing AI from regulation is good for American workers and tech innovators

title: Nvidia and Google DeepMind will help power Disney’s cute robots

- Newton will be used to power Disney's next-generation entertainment robots, including Star Wars-inspired BDX droids.
- An open-source version of Newton is set to release later in 2025.
- Disney plans to showcase its robots at theme parks starting next year, citing readiness due to Newton.
- Newton helps robots handle complex tasks and enhances interactivity with deformable objects.
- The engine is compatible with Google DeepMind’s tools and technologies for robotic development.
- Nvidia announced other products at GTC 2025, including Groot N1, a foundation model for humanoid robots.

sources.title: Nvidia and Google DeepMind will help power Disney’s cute robots

summary:

title: Tesla Awarded Ride-Hail Permit in California: First Step Toward Robotaxis
summary:
- Tesla received a permit from the California Public Utilities Commission to operate a transportation service.
- The permit does not cover autonomous vehicle testing or deployment and is limited to employee transportation.
- Tesla plans to notify CPUC when it starts transporting the public.
- Unlike ride-hailing companies, the permit is different and does not allow for driverless rides in California yet.
- Tesla intends to launch a robotaxi service in Austin, Texas, in June with its Full Self-Driving software.
- CEO Elon Musk announced that testing of driverless operations will begin in Texas during the summer.
- There are concerns about Tesla's optimistic timelines for fully autonomous vehicles and the technology's readiness.

summary:
- Tesla CEO Elon Musk presents the prototype of the Cybercab, a fully driverless vehicle, at the Warner Bros. lot in Burbank, California.
- The surprise reveal included a new transport vehicle called the Robovan, which can be configured for mass transit or cargo.
- Musk acknowledges delays in developing a driverless vehicle, previously stating such technology was only 'two years away'.
- Reactions to the event may determine Musk’s ability to deliver competitive self-driving technology.

- The Cybercab will charge wirelessly using an inductive charger, a technology Tesla has been teasing for years.

title: NASA astronauts return from long Space Station stay prompted by Boeing problems
summary:
- Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore returned to Earth after a nine-month stay on the ISS due to Boeing Starliner's issues.
- They splashed down in the Gulf of Mexico in a SpaceX Dragon capsule after a 17-hour return journey.
- The mission duration was extended because of leaks and thruster problems with the Starliner spacecraft.
- Initially launched in June 2024, the mission was meant to help Boeing compete with SpaceX's historic crewed flights.
- NASA and SpaceX coordinated to bring the astronauts back early in 2025 to avoid short-staffing the ISS.
- Elon Musk claimed he offered to bring them home sooner, a statement disputed by former NASA officials and White House sources.

summary: • A new spin-off podcast, The Young Old Derf Chronicles, is being produced by Maximum Fun. • The series will consist of eight episodes focusing on the character Old Derf and his backstory. • Original cast members and co-creators including Justin Tyler and Jeremy Bent will return for this project. • The podcast aims to expand the Zyxx Quadrant Sonicmatic Universe in a humorous way. • No firm release date, but the podcast is expected to debut in late 2025, with bonus episodes leading up to the launch.

title: Apple reveals Passwords app vulnerability exposed to phishing attacks for three months.
summary:
- Apple fixed a vulnerability in the iOS 18.2 Passwords app that lasted for three months, making users susceptible to phishing attacks.
- The vulnerability allowed unencrypted requests for icons next to stored passwords, allowing attackers on the same network to direct users to phishing sites.
- Discovered by Mysk in September 2024, Apple confirmed the bug's existence in their security updates on March 17, 2025.

sources.title: Apple reveals Passwords app vulnerability exposed to phishing attacks for three months.

title: Nvidia announces DGX desktop “personal AI supercomputers”
summary:
- Nvidia unveiled two personal AI supercomputers: DGX Spark and DGX Station, powered by the Grace Blackwell platform.
- The systems are designed for running neural networks and target developers, researchers, and data scientists.
- DGX Spark features up to 1,000 trillion operations per second; DGX Station includes 784GB of memory and high network speeds.
- Major manufacturers like Asus, Dell, HP, and Lenovo will produce these systems, with DGX Spark reservations opening now and DGX Station expected later in 2025.
- Pricing is not specified, but a base configuration for a similar system was previously estimated at around $3,000.

title: Nvidia Unveils New AI Chips: Blackwell Ultra and Rubin Series
summary:
- Nvidia announces two new AI chips: Blackwell Ultra GB300 and Vera Rubin.
- Blackwell Ultra GB300 expected to ship in the second half of 2025; Vera Rubin and Rubin Ultra set for 2026 and 2027 respectively.
- Blackwell Ultra features 20 petaflops of AI performance with 288GB of HBM3e memory.
- A Blackwell Ultra DGX GB300 cluster includes 288 CPUs, 576 GPUs, and 11.5 exaflops of FP4 computing.
- Vera Rubin aims for 50 petaflops of FP4 performance; total system performance can reach 3.6 exaflops in a full rack.
- Rubin Ultra will offer 100 petaflops of FP4 precision and 15 exaflops of inference compute, expected in late 2027.
- Each Rubin Ultra GPU will feature 1TB of HBM4e memory in a system with 365TB total memory.
- Nvidia's founder anticipates a surge in computing power demand, predicting a need for "100 times more than last year."

title: AI is making organized crime worse in the EU, Europol warns
summary:
- Europol warns that artificial intelligence is intensifying organized crime in the EU, affecting societal foundations.
- The warning coincided with the release of the EU Serious and Organized Crime Threat Assessment 2025 report.
- AI-driven cybercrime poses a digital arms race against governments, businesses, and individuals.
- The report highlights a rise in offenses like drug trafficking, money laundering, and online scams due to AI.
- Significant increase in child sexual abuse material online is attributed to AI's ability to create difficult-to-analyze imagery.
- AI technologies enable new forms of fraud, extortion, and identity theft through realistic synthetic media and voice cloning.

summary:

title: Ban smartphones for UK under-16s, urges Adolescence writer
summary:
- Jack Thorne proposes that smartphones be banned for under-16s in the UK, comparing them to cigarettes.
- He emphasizes the dangers of social media algorithms that can lead teenagers to harmful online spaces.
- Thorne calls for radical government action similar to regulations in France, Norway, and Australia regarding teen access to social media.
- The Netflix show *Adolescence*, co-written by Thorne, has sparked discussions about the influence of incel culture and misogyny online.
- The show depicts a 13-year-old protagonist caught in these dangerous environments, highlighting the perception and meanings of emojis among teens.
- Academics warn about rising anti-feminist sentiments fueled by social media platforms and the need for vigilance against incel culture's symbols and language.
- The recently enacted Online Safety Act in the UK aims to control harmful content but faces challenges in identifying incel-related emojis.

summary:

- GM will utilize Nvidia’s Omniverse and AI training software for robotics and manufacturing efficiency.
- Enhanced vehicles will feature Nvidia’s Drive AGX system-on-a-chip for autonomous capabilities and high-performance compute.
- GM's past efforts with autonomous vehicles have faced challenges and funding cuts following safety concerns.
- Nvidia expects its automotive sector to grow significantly despite current low penetration in vehicle markets.
- This partnership adds GM to a growing list of automakers collaborating with Nvidia.
- General Motors (GM) partners with Nvidia to integrate AI across its operations, including factories and self-driving cars.
- Nvidia will supply AI infrastructure, including GPUs, and assist GM in building custom AI systems.
- GM to utilize Nvidia Omniverse with Cosmos for training AI models to enhance factory design and robotics.

title: Google Acquires Wiz for $32 Billion; Armis Purchases Otorio for $120 Million
summary:
- Armis acquires Otorio for $120 million in cash and shares, enhancing cybersecurity in industrial and physical environments.
- Otorio’s flagship product, Titan, will integrate into Armis’ Centrix platform.
- This acquisition marks Armis’ third purchase in a year, following Silk Security and CTCI acquisitions.
- The move is part of a trend where early-stage cyber startups opt for acquisitions as funding becomes concentrated in late-stage companies.
- Otorio specializes in operational technology security, complementing Armis' portfolio.
- Google announced its plan to acquire Wiz for $32 billion, marking the largest acquisition in its history and the biggest exit in Israeli history.
- Wiz, founded in January 2020, rapidly grew into a unicorn and significantly increased its valuation over the years, reaching $12 billion by May 2023.
- The company gained attention for identifying vulnerabilities across major cloud platforms, including Microsoft Azure, and raised concerns about sensitive AI data exposure.
- Initially, Google offered $23 billion for Wiz but was rejected, leading Wiz to consider an IPO due to regulatory concerns about Big Tech acquisitions.

summary:

- The incidents occurred in 2021 and 2023, involving KyberSwap and Indexed Finance platforms.
- Medjedovic exploited smart contract vulnerabilities and used manipulative trading practices to maximize his theft, stealing approximately $48.8 million from 77 liquidity pools.

- Addressed past criticisms regarding character portrayal by focusing on historical accuracy.

- Gameplay combines stealth and combat, focusing on a historically engaging narrative.
- Introduces a dual protagonist system, allowing players to switch between Naoe and Yasuke after the initial gameplay.
- The narrative revolves around Naoe’s quest for vengeance and Yasuke’s journey to find his place as a samurai.
- Combat features distinct styles for each character suited for various gameplay approaches.
